authors.name: Klaus-J. Appenroth
authors.affiliation: University of Jena, Plant Physiology, Dornburger Str. 159, 07743 Jena, German

description: {"blocks":[{"key":"50j6m","text":"This protocol details about various media for in vitro-cultivation of duckweed. It contains protocols from the The International Steering Committee on Duckweed Research and Application (ISCDRA) Newsletter. A complete list of these news letters can be found here. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":257,"length":4}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"2D7F0740D98911EDB463C912EDCDE1D3","url":"http://www.ruduckweed.org/"}}}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"81dnn","text":"There is a large number of cultivation media in use for duckweed. This simply shows that most duckweed can adapt to a broad range of conditions. This does not mean that physiological responses are always the same. In order to support scientific standards for the duckweed community, we compiled the most useful nutrient media here in form of lab protocols, including the stock solutions used. All protocols are for autotrophic cultivation. If mixotrophic cultivations are required, either glucose ( ) or sucrose ( ) should be added. We have never added vitamins or other organics as green plants produce it themselves.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":498,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":513,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"43r5b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3v8s1","text":"Final concentrations are given in molar concentrations – and should be given in scientific publications. Only then different nutrient media can be compared and the data do not depend e.g. on the amount of crystal water of the substances.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8851b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8l9eb","text":"Most of the original protocols were published before FeEDTA or FeNaEDTA were available on a commercial basis. In most cases, these substance are much easier to handle than other sources of iron. Only when possible chelating effects may have an influence on the physiological effects under investigation (e.g. flowering) one should take care. All nutrient media should be autoclaved before use. The numbers in brackets are the molecular weight/ mass in g mol-1, which might help in calculations.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":457,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"concentration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"concentration":"50","error_concentration":false,"guid":"D1D39DE0A02A11ECB39691E0374D77A5","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":28}},"1":{"type":"concentration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"concentration":"25","error_concentration":false,"guid":"D7AC0BD0A02A11ECB39691E0374D77A5","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":28}}}}

references.title: Photophysiology of turion formation and germination in Spirodela polyrhiza.
references.authors: K.-J. Appenroth, S. Teller, M. Horn

references.title: Medium and Techniques for Induction and Growth of Monocotyledonous and Dicotyledonous Plant Cell Cultures.
references.authors: Schenk, R. U. and A. C. Hildebrandt

references.title: A revised medium for rapid growth and bio assay with tobacco tissue cultures

status.info: We use this protocol and it's working

Described in ISO standard (ISO 20079).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":1,"offset":319,"style":"sub"},{"length":1,"offset":372,"style":"sub"}],"key":"2h5sf","text":"This nutrient medium is recommended for investigating the effects of substances that might be chelated, e. g. heavy metals. Therefore, the concentration of chelators is so low that the optimal growth of duckweed is not possible. If you want to use this medium but want to have higher growth rates, the FeEDTA and EDTANa2 concentrations should be increased fivefold. EDTANa2 was added to keep the same ration of chelated and free EDTA as in the original Several of the components in stock solution 6 might not be required at all, e.g. KI. Landolt and Kandeler (1987) cited this version of the MS-medium according to Jacobs (1947) and mentioned that it is very rich of nitrate and potassium. They also criticized the complete lack of sodium and the low concentrations of trace Appenroth, S. Teller, M. Horn","can_edit":1,"date":"825683700","doi":"10.1007/BF02879642","guid":"A510C870A06E11ECB80B1964D23CA3DA","id":1617,"journal":"Biologia Plantarum","protocol_id":null,"title":"Photophysiology of turion formation and germination in Spirodela polyrhiza."}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":143},{"key":1,"length":1,"offset":262},{"key":2,"length":1,"offset":484},{"key":3,"length":1,"offset":491}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bkcci","text":"This medium was developed in our Institute and used for several decades for all duckweed species. The original low concentration of phosphate ( ) was used to induce turions formation. As this is rather a special case, we increased the phosphate concentration to   as given in the table. We never found nutrient media that supported a faster growth of duckweed than this one. When this nutrient medium should be used for stock cultivation, we increase the KH2PO4 concentration to even  , add   glucose and solidify by 0.9 % agar. Even after several decades of cultivation, the plants do not miss the trace elements that are not supplied. Most probably, even in chemicals of p.A.- quality, these elements are present as contaminations.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dv05c","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"concentration":"60","error_concentration":false,"guid":"E7D8BAF0A06E11ECB80B1964D23CA3DA","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":29},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"concentration"},"1":{"data":{"concentration":"150","error_concentration":false,"guid":"1A9FD860A06F11ECB80B1964D23CA3DA","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":29},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"concentration"},"2":{"data":{"concentration":"1","error_concentration":false,"guid":"27869C30A06F11ECB80B1964D23CA3DA","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":28},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"concentration"},"3":{"data":{"concentration":"50","error_concentration":false,"guid":"47931BC0A06F11ECB80B1964D23CA3DA","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":28},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"concentration"}}}},"2":{"type":"tables","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"cellsMeta":{"0_0":"","0_1":"","0_2":"","0_3":"","10_0":"","10_1":"","10_2":"","10_3":"","10_4":"","1_0":"","1_1":"","1_2":"","1_3":"","1_4":"","2_0":"","2_1":"","2_2":"","2_3":"","2_4":"","3_0":"","3_1":"","3_2":"","3_3":"","3_4":"","4_0":"","4_1":"","4_2":"","4_3":"","4_4":"","5_0":"","5_1":"","5_2":"","5_3":"","5_4":"","6_0":"","6_1":"","6_2":"","6_3":"","6_4":"","7_0":"","7_1":"","7_2":"","7_3":"","7_4":"","8_0":"","8_1":"","8_2":"","8_3":"","8_4":"","9_0":"","9_1":"","9_2":"","9_3":"","9_4":"","A_1":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"B_1":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"C_1":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"D_1":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"E_1":{"className":"_dt-bold"}},"colTitles":["","","","",""],"colWidths":[48,"167",111,"86","167"],"data":[["Stock","Compound","Stock
